newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia sees oil price stable despite Iraq oil.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia sees oil price stable despite Iraq oil.

text.p: Indonesia's state oil company Pertamina said on Tuesday it saw oil prices remaining stable despite Iraq's return to the world market under an "oil-for-food" deal with the United Nations.

"Iraqi oil will enter the market with between 600,000 barrels per day (bpd) to 800,000 bpd. This amount can be accomodated by the market. I think the price will remain stable," said Pertamina president director Faisal Abda'oe.
"If the volume of oil from Iraq is more than that level, certainly it will depress prices," Abda'oe told reporters.

The United Nations on Monday authorised the start of a long-delayed "oil-for-food" deal with Iraq, enabling Baghdad to make a limited return to the world oil market for the first time since its 1990 invasion of Kuwait.

Under the plan, concluded in May but held up by disputes over implementation, Iraq will be able to sell $2 billion worth of oil over six months to buy food, medicine and other humanitarian goods for its people, who have been suffering from sanctions imposed in August 1990.
The initial six-month period began on Tuesday.
Abda'oe said the Indonesian government must be careful in deciding the oil price for its budget in fiscal 1997/98 (April-March).
"We must be very careful in deciding (the) oil price for our next budget. I think $16.50 per barrel is still okay," he said.
Indonesia set an average price of $16.50 a barrel in its 1996/97 budget.
